sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Aortography: (Hypaque(TM)) 10 to 30 mL of 50% solution INTRA-ARTERIALLY by translumbar technique to visualize the aorta and its major branches OR 1 mL/kg IV OR 0.5 to 1 mL/kg of body weight by retrograde catheter
  • Arteriography, Peripheral: (Hypaque(TM)) 25 to 35 mL of 50% solution introduced into the larger peripheral arteries by PERCUTANEOUS or operative methods
  • Cholangiogram, Direct: (Hypaque(TM)) (operative) 10 to 15 mL of a 25% to 50% solution injected or instilled slowly without undue pressure into the cystic duct or common bile duct; may require a larger volume (up to 100 mL) in case of a dilated ductal tract
  • CT of head, Contrast enhancement: (Hypaque(TM)) 50 to 100 mL (50% solution) bolus IV injection or up to 150 mL by infusion; rate of injection depends on the pathology
  • Head angiography: (Hypaque(TM)) 8 to 10 mL of 50% solution rapidly injected at a rate not exceeding the normal flow in the carotid artery (about 5 mL per second); repeated as indicated
  • Head angiography: (Hypaque(TM)) a single injection of 35 to 50 mL by retrograde brachial or catheter method (aortic arch)
  • Hysterosalpingography: (Hypaque(TM)) approximately 4 mL of 50% solution to fill a normal uterine cavity, with an additional 3 mL or 4 mL for the fallopian tubes; amounts vary depending on the nature of the disease
  • Intraosseous venography: (Hypaque(TM)) 10 to 20 mL of 50% solution injected directly into the bone marrow after aspirating 4 mL of marrow; to visualize the pterygoid venous plexus, inject 5 to 8 mL into the medullary cavity of the mandible
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (Hypaque(TM)) 30 mL of 50% solution by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; repeated in 15 to 30 minutes if indicated; range, 30 to 60 mL; may use 20 mL in persons of slight build
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (Hypaque(TM)) 20 to 30 mL of 50% solution IM (undiluted or diluted) injected in the gluteal muscles in 2 separate, equal doses OR SUBQ (diluted with equal quantities of sterile water for injection) injected in divided equal doses over each scapula
  • Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram: (Hypaque(TM)) 20 to 40 mL of 50% solution (range, 10 to 60 mL), slowly injected into the biliary duct under very slight pressure; if a duct is not located by aspiration, successive small doses of 1 to 2 mL injected into the liver as the needle is gradually withdrawn, until a duct is visualized by x-ray
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (Hypaque(TM) sodium oral powder) 90 to 180 mL of a 25% to 40% solution ORALLY
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (Hypaque(TM) sodium oral powder) 500 to 1000 mL of a 15% to 25% solution RECTALLY
  • Renal arteriography, Selective: (Hypaque(TM)) 5 to 8 mL of 50% solution with repeated injections
  • Splenoportogram by splenic arteriography: (Hypaque(TM)) 20 to 25 mL of 50% solution rapidly injected; initially inject a small pilot dose to confirm splenic entry
  • Venography: (Hypaque(TM)) 15 to 40 mL of 50% solution by PERCUTANEOUS or operative method to visualize veins in the extremities

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Aortography: (12 years and older) (Hypaque(TM)) 10 to 30 mL of 50% solution INTRA-ARTERIALLY by translumbar technique to visualize the aorta and its major branches OR 1 mL/kg IV OR 0.5 to 1 mL/kg of body weight by retrograde catheter
  • Aortography: (less than 12 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)) 1 mL/kg of 50% solution IV OR 0.5 or 1 mL/kg of body weight INTRA-ARTERIALLY by retrograde catheter; dose of translumbar technique is proportionate to age
  • CT of head, Contrast enhancement: (Hypaque(TM)) proportional to adults (50 to 100 mL (50% solution) bolus IV injection or up to 150 mL by infusion), based on weight
  • Head angiography: (Hypaque(TM)) proportional to adult doses, based on weight
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (under 6 months of age) (Hypaque(TM)) 5 mL of 50% solution by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; repeated in 15 to 30 minutes if indicated
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (6 to 12 months of age) (Hypaque(TM)) 6 to 8 mL of 50% solution by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; repeated in 15 to 30 minutes if indicated
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (1 to 2 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)) 8 to 10 mL of 50% solution by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; repeated in 15 to 30 minutes if indicated
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (2 to 5 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)) 10 to 12 mL of 50% solution by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; repeated in 15 to 30 minutes if indicated
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (5 to 7 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)) 12 to 15 mL of 50% solution by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; repeated in 15 to 30 minutes if indicated
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (8 to 10 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)) 15 to 18 mL of 50% solution by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; repeated in 15 to 30 minutes if indicated
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (11 to 15 years of age) (Hypaque(TM)) 18 to 20 mL of 50% solution by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; repeated in 15 to 30 minutes if indicated
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (16 years or older) (Hypaque(TM)) 30 to 60 mL of 50% solution by either direct IV bolus injection or IV drip infusion; repeated in 15 to 30 minutes if indicated; range, 30 to 60 mL; may use 20 mL in persons of slight build
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (older children) (Hypaque(TM)) 20 to 30 mL of 50% solution IM (undiluted or diluted) injected in the gluteal muscles in 2 separate, equal doses OR SUBQ (diluted with equal quantities of sterile water for injection) injected in divided equal doses over each scapula
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography: (infants and young children) (Hypaque(TM)) 5 to 16 mL of 50% solution IM (undiluted or diluted) injected in the gluteal muscles in 2 separate, equal doses OR SUBQ (diluted with equal quantities of sterile water for injection) injected in divided equal doses over each scapula
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (Hypaque(TM) sodium oral powder) 30 to 75 mL of a 20% to 40% solution ORALLY
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract: (Hypaque(TM) sodium oral powder) 100 to 500 mL of a 10% to 15% solution RECTALLY, depending on patient's weight
  • Renal arteriography, Selective: (older than 14 years) (Hypaque(TM)) 5 to 8 mL of 50% solution with repeated injections
  • Renal arteriography, Selective: (younger than 14 years) (Hypaque(TM)) dose is proportionate to age

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: (pancreatitis patients) (Hypaque(TM)) for direct cholangiography, inject no more than 5 to 10 mL without undue pressure

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Aortography
  • Arteriography, Peripheral
  • Cholangiogram, Direct
  • CT of head, Contrast enhancement
  • Head angiography
  • Hysterosalpingography
  • Intraosseous venography
  • Intravenous pyelogram, Excretory urography
  • Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram
  • Radiography of gastrointestinal tract
  • Renal arteriography, Selective
  • Splenoportogram by splenic arteriography
  • Venography

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• when used as recommended, there are no specific contraindications for administration of oral solution and no absolute contraindication for administration of injection
  • administration into subarachnoid space; even small amounts may cause convulsions and death (injection)
  • dehydrated azotemic patients; urography and large-dose vascular procedures are contraindicated (injection)
  • epidural administration (injection)
  • intrathecal administrations; increased risk of severe adverse events (injection)
  • myelography or examination of dorsal cysts or sinuses (injection)

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• brain metastases; increased risk of seizures when high doses of ionic contrast media are given during CT scan (injection)
  • bronchial asthma or allergy, personal or family history of; increased risk of drug hypersensitivity reaction (injection)
  • cellular injury to circulating lymphocytes; increased risk with contrast media administered for cardiac catheterization and angiocardiography (injection)
  • concomitant general anesthesia; may increase risk of adverse effects due to reduced cardiac output and increased duration of contrast agent exposure (injection)
  • congestive heart failure; risk with injection of urographic agents due to the transitory increase in the circulatory osmotic load (injection)
  • diabetes; preparatory dehydration for angiography and CT procedures may contribute to renal failure (injection)
  • diabetes with diabetic neuropathy; risk of acute renal failure following excretory urography (injection)
  • elderly patients; preparatory dehydration for angiography and CT procedures may contribute to renal failure (injection)
  • electrolyte imbalances; increased risk of shock caused by hypertonic preparations, especially in young or debilitated children and elderly cachectic patients (oral, rectal)
  • hepatic disease, severe; increased risk of adverse effects (oral, rectal, injection)
  • highly hypertonic solutions; may draw excessive amounts of contrast medium into the intestine and cause hypervolemia (oral, rectal)
  • homocystinuria, pre-existing; increased risk of inducing thrombosis and embolism with angiography (injection)
  • hypersensitivity to diatrizoic acid compounds, history of; consider benefit to risk ratio (oral or rectal)
  • hypersensitivity history or symptoms such as bronchial asthma, hay fever, and food allergies; increased risk of idiosyncratic reaction
  • hyperthyroidism or patients with an autonomously functioning thyroid nodule; risk of thyroid storm following intravascular use (injection)
  • infants and young children; preparatory dehydration for angiography and CT procedures may contribute to renal failure; increased risk of convulsions, especially with repeated injections (injection)
  • low-injection sites (L2 to L3); increased risk of neurologic complications, including paraplegia, with aortography (injection)
  • multiple myeloma; precipitation of myeloma protein in renal tubules may cause anuria, leading to progressive uremia, renal failure, and death, with excretory urography (injection)
  • pheochromocytoma, known or suspected; risk of a hypertensive crisis (injection)
  • renal disease, severe; increased risk of adverse effects (oral, rectal, or injection)
  • sensitivity to iodine or other contrast agents, history; possibility of an idiosyncratic reaction (injection)
  • sickle cell disease, homozygous; intravenous or intra-arterial administration may precipitate sickling (injection)
  • spinal anesthesia; increased risk of neurologic complications (including paraplegia) with aortography (injection)
  • subarachnoid hemorrhage; risk of clinical deterioration, including convulsions and death (injection)
  • vascular disease; increased risk for subcutaneous extravasation and sloughing of skin, especially in poorly vascularized areas (eg; dorsum of the foot or hand) (injection)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Diatrizoate: AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Diatrizoate: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Vasodilatation (49%)
  • Dermatologic:Injection site pain (about 12%), Urticaria (1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (6%), Taste sense altered (11%), Vomiting (3%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (5%), Paresthesia (6%)
  • Renal:Hypokalemic nephropathy (23% (after excretory urography))
  • Respiratory:Cough (2%), Rhinitis (1%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac arrest (less than 1%), Shock (0.005%), Ventricular fibrillation (less than 1%)
  • Dermatologic:Necrosis / ulceration of skin due to extravasation of drug (less than 1%)
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia (less than 1%)
  • Neurologic:Coma (less than 1%), Paralysis (less than 1%), Seizure (less than 1%)
  • Renal:Renal failure (less than 1%)
  • Respiratory:Bronchospasm (less than 1%), Pulmonary edema (less than 1%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The use of diatrizoate is not based on its pharmacologic properties, but on its distribution and elimination from the body. The iodine content of a contrast media is the most important factor, since this component is responsible for the absorption of radiation and the degree of opacification. The high atomic weight of iodine contributes sufficient x-radiation attenuation to impart radiographic contrast with surrounding tissue. Diagnostic radiopaque agents have few known pharmacological effects.

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono: Protein binding: 0% to 10% bound to serum albumin

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: (intravenous), less than 2%
  • Renal: (intravenous), 12% within 10 minutes, 38% at 60 minutes, 45% at 3 hours, and 94% to 100% at 24 hours excreted unchanged

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Intravenous
    • do NOT administer by intrathecal route
    • solution should be at body temperature when injected; may need to be warmed
    • if crystallization occurs, place the vial in a water bath at 40 to 50 degrees C and shake it gently for 2 to 3 minutes or until solids redissolve; discard the vial if particles still persist
    • solution may be autoclaved once
    • do not contaminate catheters, syringes, needles, and contrast media with glove powder or cotton fibers
    • discard any unused portion
    • (angiography), flush the catheter frequently with heparinized saline solutions; use plastic syringes in place of glass to decrease the likelihood of in vitro clotting
  • Oral
    • (Hypaque(TM) sodium oral powder) use 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, or 4 measuring spoons of powder (approximately 10 g of powder per measuring spoon level) per 100 mL of diluent (eg; water, milk, or a carbonated drink) to make 10%, 15%, 20%, 25%, or 40% solutions, respectively
    • use solution immediately after preparation and discard after use
  • Rectal
    • (Hypaque(TM) sodium oral powder) use 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, or 4 measuring spoons of powder (approximately 10 g of powder per measuring spoon level) per 100 mL of diluent (eg; water, milk, or a carbonated drink) to make 10%, 15%, 20%, 25%, or 40% solutions, respectively
    • use solution immediately after preparation and discard after use

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• image quality and diagnostic usefulness
  • vital signs; baseline and then periodically
  • ECG; baseline and then periodically as clinically indicated
  • injection site reactions; frequently for any signs of extravasation
  • renal and hepatic function; baseline and then periodically as clinically indicated
  • signs and symptoms of iodine or other contrast agents sensitivity; during procedure and then for 30 to 60 minutes after the procedure
  • thyroid function tests (T3 resin uptake and total or free thyroxine (T4) assays); at baseline and after procedure as clinically indicated

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as the injection drug may cause dizziness.
  • Instruct patient to rise slowly from a sitting/supine position, as the injection drug may cause hypotension.
  • The oral form of this drug may cause nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and urticaria.
  • The injection form of this drug may cause vasodilation, paresthesia, nausea, vomiting, cough, and perversion of taste.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of thyroid storm (chest pain, tachycardia, dyspnea, fever, anxiety).
  • Instruct patients to be fully hydrated before procedures (with the possible exception of urography).
